Morgana. In lane you sit back until you have 3 charges of Spellthief. Then walk forward, W under the champ's feet, and walk back.

When your jungle comes in for a gank, throw your Q. By the time the enemy is free to move again they'll be at -500.

In team fights press E on someone important. It lasts for ages, half of the enemy team can't pop it, and it gives CC immunity.

Then flash into the middle of the enemy team and press R + whatever hotkey Zhonya's is bound to. 

Congratulations, you just hit Plat V as a support main.

Thresh is far from easy are you for real???
I'm the only person I've seen use his Q+W combo, and it's because it's all about proper placing and timing. 
Drop your lantern, land your hook, reactivate hook as soon as ally activates lantern. It's not easy. 

Not to mention- you run the risk of allies not knowing how to use your lantern the way you're intending. So Thresh requires a lot of communication- something that doesn't go well in this community. 

Overall- Thresh is very fun to play. And if you get the chance- play 3s with an Azir and Kalista as your allies. The skating is unreal if you all cooperate.

That is true, new Taric has to play a bit more with his ally, time his ult right and make better use of his passive. At the same time, though, he's still relatively simple (the only skill that really requires aiming is his E, and its hitbox is fairly generous), and unlike some other supports, it's relatively easy to see exactly where he shines and how. Even if you have no idea how to make optimal use of his W, E or ult, pressing buttons can still impact meaningfully on a fight and help out your allies.

Easy would be morgana, sona, nami, raka, the babysitter style supports.

Fun supports depend on your playstyle, so whatever is fun is up to you.

If you're new to the support role i do recomend learning a few adcs, or at least researching then. Just to get a feel on what they do and need from a support. Most importantly however, make sure you purchase (and use!) sightstone.
